ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a fantastic course, as both a Bible class and an English course. It was very different from any other English class I've taken, but it helps that Mr. Brisman emphasized intellectualizing the Bible, meaning considering it not necessarily only as a religious text but also as a body of work written by different authors. I think out of all the English class I've taken, it was the one in which historical context mattered most, which was valuable to consider.
This course assisted in deepening my grasp on the English language.
The course helped fine-tune a lot of grammatical challenges in my writing and challenged me not to write along with a strict argument.
I got a chance to really work on my close reading skills and my writing abilities!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Mr. Brisman was great at encouraging participation and demonstrating his value of student voices in class. I think I might have been helpful to spend some more time in class focused solely on the secondary texts concerning the synoptic problem and the documentary hypothesis, although I appreciated the required response papers on those topics.

I wouldn't change anything about this course! Some of my favorite parts of the class were the introductory writing assignments in which we were asked to put the introduction of the New Jerusalem Bible translation in conversation with the writings of other biblical scholars and the requirement/encouragement to consult a piece of literary criticism in writing our three essays. This introduction to and participation in the greater field of biblical literary criticism was a strength of the course. Another strength was Prof. Brisman's teaching style of making many analogies to current events. The constant reminder of the relevancy of the course material to our daily lives made each discussion and this feel all the more important.

I loved how discussion-based classes were: we had remarkably intriguing and lively discussions every class. Mr. Brisman would also give an interesting introduction at the beginning of every section, but I wish those introductions would be a little bit longer and more like mini-lectures!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course would have been a lot more enjoyable in person. The class was slightly boring, and i think the professor could make some changes on presenting the material.
The class was small and participation was lively. The presence of a teaching fellow also made the course much more accessible.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely. The Bible is a book that everyone should read and understand because of its importance in Western literature and this course is a great opportunity to read it in an academic environment.

Definitely take this course! Mr. Brisman is clearly so knowledgeable about the Bible, and it helps to learn about it in an academic context where students are encouraged to engage with it as "a Literature," not just a holy text.
No, I think it would take a high-interest level in the material to make it enjoyable. The class can be slow and at times boring.
Yes! This class will alter how you perceive or understand the Bible and will make you into a better reader, writer, and human being!
Yes! The material is super interesting, and I've learned so much about reading and writing from Mr. Brisman. Whether you're a major or not, you won't regret it!

extras.title:
ENGL 395 01/HUMS 380 01/LITR 154 01
        The Bible as a Literature
